title: Farm Animal Sounds Song S0101 | Little Bunny Learns | Nursery Rhymes

subtasks: Listen to animal sounds) and then repeat them (SUBTASK: Recall and repeat animal sounds). That would make sense as a language exercise for a child or someone learning farm animals.
Identify animals on the farm) is part of this. So when they mention each animal (pigeon, bull, calf, chick, donkey, llama, goose, dove), the person has to match the animal to its sound.

Animals on the farm" with subtasks identifying animals and sounds. If they've specified animals and sounds, that's good. Now cross-check with the student's version.
Listen to the animals
What sounds do the animals make?

Listen to animal sounds

Since that's how it was structured in the original answer. Though combined into one MAINTASK, splitting it helps too. But the point is to cover identifying and reciting. The idea of "learn the animal sounds on the farm," yes, that would require listening (hearing them, perhaps even in a farm setting) and then repeating.
MAINTASK of listening with subtasks identifying and recalling. The crux is that someone is to anticipate the sound and then produce the correct sound, hence the need to have both identify and repeat.
Listen to animal sounds
subtasks: Identify the animals (pigeon, bull, calf, chick, donkey, llama, goose, dove)
Repeat the animal sounds (Coo, Nort, Moo, Peep, Bray, Hum, Hiss, Coo)

Identify and recall the animal sounds on the farm, with relevant subtasks. Since those are just different aspects, it's appropriate.
Identify animals on the farm
Recall animal sounds

Then the answer would combine both subtasks, but splitting into two MAINTASK. This is acceptable as it reflects different stages. The primary action is identifying and then recalling. But given that the answer doesn't need to be rigid, and someone may choose to combine them. Yet separating them may be necessary.
But after reviewing, the MAINTASKs "Identify the animals on the farm" and "Recall the animal sounds" leading to the subtasks makes sense.
